@apapanico I think you're encountering a common problem having to do with the start date -- Airflow schedules DAGs for the period AFTER the start date, not ON the start date. (For example, the daily run for a DAG on 3/25 actually starts on 3/26). Since your start date is always read as "right now", the scheduler never gets to the "next" period. Try making your start_date `now() + timedelta(days=-1)` and I think it should work.
@timseries I think that would be a good enhancement. Would you like to make a PR for it? Adding a `pandas_params` dict should do the trick.

![img](https://media.giphy.com/media/5MDk34NOY6ili/giphy.gif)
Should this not be fixed in configuration.py itself? Eg. if "None" is found, we don't set a value? if != 'None' is bound to have some fix it by doing a "if is not None" in the future

The issue is that I had unwittingly added `remote_base_log_folder = None` to the `airflow.cfg` template, so anyone who regenerated airflow.cfg in the last month or so has a string value "None" there. It shouldn't actually be `"None"` or even `None` (the Python object); the real default is `''`. So I added that line just to cover people who installed Airflow prior to this PR going into a release.

Ah okay.  Thanks for that suggestion.  I updated that part to `datetime.now() + timedelta(days=-2)`, reset the db, and restarted the server.  Still nothing running though.  Does Airflow wait until the next day to start or should I expect it to kick off immediately?

It should start right away -- I see it running under 1.6.2 and master. Only because you didn't mention it, did you restart your scheduler?

What I'm doing:

```
[put the code in the dags folder]
airflow resetdb -y
airflow webserver
airflow scheduler
```

And I see it start to run after a few seconds.

Oh geez..... I am an idiot.  I was not going `airflow scheduler`.  It's working.  Sorry about this.  Read the docs more closely, Alex.  I thought the whole operation was done through `airflow webserver`.

No worries! I've made the same mistake more times than I should admit. Airflow has a lot of components and it can be confusing to get going, but we want to make it as easy as possible. If there's anything that would have been more helpful to you (like a more concise/explicit explanation of the role of the scheduler vs the webserver), please let us know or consider adding it to the docs yourself!

Code quality remained the same when pulling **[76dc77d](https://github.com/gentnerlab/airflow/commit/76dc77d6bf453ff1491599069758ddf22881e109) on gentnerlab:gentnerlab** into **[0f28090](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/0f28090fa05b181423961bc9170b1195153127c0) on airbnb:master**.

I am seeing infinite retries with pools using the current bleeding-edge repo(0f28090fa05b181423961bc9170b1195153127c0). You can replicate this issue with the following dag, which assumes the existence of a pool called "TrivialTasks":

```
#!/bin/env python                                                                                                                                                                                           
from airflow import DAG
from airflow.operators import PythonOperator
from datetime import datetime, timedelta


default_args = {
        'owner': 'airflow',
        'depends_on_past': False,
        'start_date': datetime(2016, 4, 2),
        'email': ['airflow@airflow.com'],
        'email_on_failure': False,
        'email_on_retry': False,
        'retries': 1,
        'retry_delay': timedelta(minutes=1)
    }

dag = DAG('fail', default_args=default_args)


def fail_func():
    raise Exception("Failure!")


t1 = PythonOperator(
    python_callable=fail_func,
    task_id='fail',
    dag=dag,
    pool="TrivialTasks")
```

This is be related to #1225, except that there's infinite retry even without using `SubDagOperator`.

Are you running a scheduler? If so I think this is the culprit: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/5ab256780ab4006f4a6fc1d1ef5d0f07d4e934ca/airflow/jobs.py#L417

If a DAG has not been scheduled before, but has been run, then the scheduler tries to start it up from 5 days before the last run. It's a little odd -- I have no idea what the significance of the 5 days is. When I came across it I didn't want to take it out completely because it might have deeper meaning, so I added a catch so that it won't schedule prior to the `start_date`.

I really like this idea. In fact I would like to use this to eliminate the short circuit operator (because even though it was created to make a confusing situation simpler, it's still pretty confusing). With a `pre_execute()` hook that possibly raises an `AirflowSkipException`, ANY operator can short-circuit.

I still need to look at the implementation but here are a couple thoughts:
- please add some unit tests. I have some open PRs that make these sort of tests easier; let me know if you'd like help setting them up. 
- errors are the primary means of communicating state to processes in Airflow. I think it would be best to subclass `AirflowException` and maybe call this something less frightening like `AirflowOperatorSkip`
- following up that idea, it would be nice to analogously raise `AirflowOperatorFail` or `AirflowDagDeadlock` as appropriate... If they were also subclasses that could be done with minimal code changes. That could be a separate PR.
Yep, figured out that out reading the tests failures. Actually I am unsure of how to test the logs without mocking in this case, and I am not sure of the added value here.
Didn't know we had that file, that's great! Yes, I'll update it.

Just after posting this issue I found the solution: It works fine when I set the start_date explicitly in DAG instanciation. I assumed that the DAG would take the start date from the default args, but they seem to be only for the task instances. With the following dag definition I get the desired behaviour:

```
from __future__ import division, absolute_import, print_function                   

from datetime import datetime, timedelta                                           

from airflow import DAG                                                            
from airflow.operators import (                                                    
    DummyOperator                                                                  
)                                                                                  


default_args = {                                                                   
    'owner': 'airflow',                                                            
    'depends_on_past': False,                                                      
    'start_date': datetime.now() - timedelta(minutes=1),                           
    'email': ['airflow@airflow.com'],                                              
    'email_on_failure': False,                                                     
    'email_on_retry': False,                                                       
    'retries': 0,                                                                  
    'retry_delay': timedelta(seconds=30)                                           
}                                                                                  

dag = DAG(                                                                         
    'test_scheduler',                                                              
    schedule_interval='0 9 * * *',                                                 
    start_date=datetime.now() - timedelta(minutes=1),                           
    default_args=default_args)                                                     

dummy = DummyOperator(task_id='dummy_op', dag=dag)    
```

@pradhanpk task instances are hashable and added/removed from sets and dicts in many places in Airflow's code. Does this not work for you?

``` python
import airflow
import datetime
from airflow.models import DAG, TaskInstance as TI
from airflow.operators import DummyOperator

start_date = datetime.datetime(2016, 1, 1)

dag = DAG('dag')
op = DummyOperator(task_id='op', dag=dag, start_date=start_date, owner='airflow')
ti = TI(op, start_date)
ti.__hash__() # [hash]

test_set = set()
test_set.add(ti)
len(test_set) # 1
test_set.remove(ti)
len(test_set) # 0
```

It looks like the problem you're seeing is simply because `prioritized_queued` doesn't clear the `queued_tis` set after it iterates over it. I will add that to the second round of job fixes that are coming in #1290.

Coverage increased (+0.6%) to 67.631% when pulling **fcc928aaae99c74a2d9c87a94ff44f1b34af51f2 on jlowin:subdag-backfill-status** into **0bae60ff84a8dc8b3deb1e856757c752ac1d714e on airbnb:master**.

@jlowin I think the issue is that you want two `TaskInstance`s to be equal when their `(dag_id, task_id, execution_date)`'s match(like in the `__eq__` implementation in this PR), since this is the primary key of the `TaskInstance` ORM. The problem without this can be seen in this modification of your example:

```
import airflow
import datetime
import copy
from airflow.models import DAG, TaskInstance as TI
from airflow.operators import DummyOperator

start_date = datetime.datetime(2016, 1, 1)

dag = DAG('dag')
op = DummyOperator(task_id='op', dag=dag, start_date=start_date, owner='airflow')
ti = TI(op, start_date)
ti.__hash__() # [hash]

test_set = set()
test_set.add(ti)
len(test_set) # 1

copy_ti = copy.deepcopy(ti)
copy_ti in test_set #False
test_set.remove(copy_ti) #KeyError
```

Isn't `elif ti in self.queued_tis:` more like `copy_ti in test_set`, rather than `ti in test_set`?

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/5661282/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/5661282)

Coverage increased (+0.7%) to 67.76% when pulling **8f7e5d44b442b7185919866c43edccef313f0533 on jlowin:subdag-backfill-status** into **0bae60ff84a8dc8b3deb1e856757c752ac1d714e on airbnb:master**.

Ah, I understand what you mean. I don't think we want to force TI equality, though. If I create two Tis, they are _not_ the same thing. However there is already a `.key` property which accomplishes much of what you're looking for if you do need to determine equality.

The issue you're trying to correct, where Tis are removed from `queued_tasks`, is a red herring -- it's not impacting the execution anymore (because `queued_tasks` is completely cleared shortly thereafter). I will delete the line entirely to make that clear -- as you point outed, it's not actually doing anything anyway!
@syvineckruyk there are a lot of fixes in this PR so I'm going to say it's "done" -- still thinking about one of the cases we discussed offline and will address it separately.
